articles.headline: In France, a Baby Switch and a Lesson in Maternal Love
articles.snippet: When a woman learned that her daughter was not her biological child, she discovered a new meaning of family.
articles.abstract: When a woman learned that her daughter was not her biological child, she discovered a new meaning of family.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRASSE, France — When Sophie Serrano finally held her daughter, Manon, in her arms after the newborn, suffering from jaundice, had been placed under artificial light, she was taken aback by the baby’s full head of glossy hair.

articles.headline: Shire, Maker of Binge-Eating Drug Vyvanse, First Marketed the Disease
articles.snippet: The strategy for a new drug to treat binge-eating disorder reveals how a pharmaceutical company can influence the treatment of a medical condition.
articles.abstract: The strategy for a new drug to treat binge-eating disorder reveals how a pharmaceutical company can influence the treatment of a medical condition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The retired tennis player Monica Seles spent this month making the rounds of television talk shows, appearing on everything from “Good Morning America” to “The Dr. Oz Show” to share her personal struggle with binge eating.

articles.headline: Putting a Price on Simon Kuznets’s Nobel in Economics
articles.snippet: The medal awarded in 1971 to the economist who created standard measures of national income and economic growth is on the auction block.
articles.abstract: The medal awarded in 1971 to the economist who created standard measures of national income and economic growth is on the auction block.
articles.lead_paragraph: James D. Watson’s sold for $4.76 million while the one owned by William Randal Cremer, a member of Parliament and labor activist, fetched just $17,000.

articles.headline: In Tepid Housing Market, Builders Cater to Desires of Well-Off
articles.snippet: Home sales of $1 million and higher account for only a small share of the overall market, but it is an increasingly reliable sweet spot for building companies.
articles.abstract: Home sales of $1 million and higher account for only a small share of the overall market, but it is an increasingly reliable sweet spot for building companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Lisa Gray spent a few months searching for a home that would span the generations, one where her two sons would want to bring friends throughout their teenage years and that her aging parents could navigate with ease.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Net Neutrality Rules Clear Hurdle as Republicans Concede to Obama
articles.snippet: The Republican resistance in Congress surrendered to President Obama’s call to protect an open Internet, with rules likely to be approved by regulators on Thursday.
articles.abstract: The Republican resistance in Congress surrendered to President Obama’s call to protect an open Internet, with rules likely to be approved by regulators on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Republicans conceded on Tuesday that the grueling fight with President Obama over the regulation of Internet service appears over, with the president and an army of Internet activists victorious.

articles.headline: Globalization That Works for Workers at Home
articles.snippet: Writing labor and environmental standards into international trade agreements has had little effect. Perhaps real change should start at home.
articles.abstract: Writing labor and environmental standards into international trade agreements has had little effect. Perhaps real change should start at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mickey Kantor has a vivid memory of August 1993. The North American Free Trade Agreement was in trouble. Though the agreement had been signed the year before, during the administration of George H.W. Bush, the newly elected Bill Clinton had promised to attach side deals to the pact to guarantee minimum labor and environmental standards.

articles.headline: Teenage Girl Leaves for ISIS, and Others Follow
articles.snippet: Aqsa Mahmood, who went to Syria in 2013 and is seen as a jihadist recruiter, may be linked to three girls from London who are believed to be enlisting.
articles.abstract: Aqsa Mahmood, who went to Syria in 2013 and is seen as a jihadist recruiter, may be linked to three girls from London who are believed to be enlisting.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Aqsa Mahmood’s family saw her as an intelligent and popular teenager who helped care for her three younger siblings and her grandparents at her home in Scotland. She listened to Coldplay, read Harry Potter novels and drank Irn Bru, a Scottish soft drink.

articles.headline: In Greek Crisis, Rare Moment of Consensus
articles.snippet: Conflict between a new generation of populist Greek leaders and their European creditors was put aside as an agreement was reached to extend the country’s bailout program four months.
articles.abstract: Conflict between a new generation of populist Greek leaders and their European creditors was put aside as an agreement was reached to extend the country’s bailout program four months.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — For the past month, as Greece once again emerged as a threat to the global economy, a new generation of populist Greek leaders vowed to shatter Europe’s austerity politics in what threatened to become an unbridgeable divide with the European establishment, especially Germany. There were insults, predictions of calamity and accusations of double-dealing and deceit.

articles.headline: Google Plans New Headquarters, and a City Fears Being Overrun
articles.snippet: Google’s sometimes testy relationship with community leaders in Mountain View, Calif., a city already bursting at the seams, is likely to get testier.
articles.abstract: Google’s sometimes testy relationship with community leaders in Mountain View, Calif., a city already bursting at the seams, is likely to get testier.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Apple is moving into Silicon Valley headquarters that look like a spaceship. Facebook is expanding its campus with a new building designed by Frank Gehry. Now it’s Google’s turn.
